Body:
BC-PHOTO-FULL-UPDATE-NYT 
   ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving 03/26/99. Photo clients will
automatically receive these photos via AP's PhotoExpress or may
download them from either the Wieck Photo Database in Dallas at
972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at 305-448-8411.
Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling (888) 603-1036
or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT34) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- KOSOVO-U.S.-SCHOOLS, 3-26
-- Putting global military action into comprehensible terms falls
to teachers like James Patsaricas, shown discussing the bombing of
Yugoslav targets with 10th-graders Friday at Edward R. Murrow High
School in Brooklyn. To understand Stalin, he says, ``you need to
understand someone named Slobodan Milosevic,'' the president of
Yugoslavia. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT33) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28 --
INVEST-TICKER-PRICES, 3-26 -- A pedestrian pauses to check prices
on the Morgan Stanley Building on Broadway. Ownership of
stock-price data is a contentious issue. (Carrie Boretz/New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT32) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28 --
BIZ-HOMELESS-MEN-3, 3-26 -- Samine Gibson of the Bronx, who wants a
job in music engineering, began his makeover by a new nonprofit
organization called Career Gear in a sweater and slacks and exited
with a trimmed beard and about $1,700 worth of business clothing.
``I feel like a million bucks,'' exults Gibson. (Fred R. Conrad/New
York Times Photo)

   (NYT31) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28 --
BIZ-HOMELESS-MEN-2, 3-26 -- Samine Gibson of the Bronx, who wants a
job in music engineering, began his makeover in a sweater and
slacks and exited with about $1,700 worth of business clothing. ``I
feel like a million bucks,'' exults Gibson. ``It's my first suit
since I was little. It makes me want to go out and get a job right
now.'' (Fred R. Conrad/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT30) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- BIZ-HOMELESS-MEN-1, 3-26
-- Samine Gibson of the Bronx, who wants a job in music
engineering, began his makeover by a new nonprofit organization
called Career Gear in a sweater and slacks. Each of the 19 men who
showed up got a haircut and grooming tips from professional
stylists, and each received about $1,700 worth of business
clothing, including a trench coat, a suit, a dress shirt, a tie, a
Coach watch and a pair of socks and Rockport shoes. (Fred R.
Conrad/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT29) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- RUSSIA-STUDIES, 3-26 --
Stephen F. Cohen, a professor of Russian studies at New York
University and the author of ``Rethinking the Soviet Experience,''
accuses Russia scholars of creating an ``intellectual shambles'' of
their field. They have ignored the country's unique history and
contemporary economic conditions, he argues, and insists that
free-market ``shock therapy'' is the only way Russia can transform
itself into a capitalist democracy. (Suzanne DeChillo/New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT28) SAN JOSE, Calif. -- March 26, 1999 -- ARATON-COLUMN,
3-26 -- Georgia's Kelly Miller tries to get around Nicole Erickson
of Duke University during the first half of the national semifinals
on Friday. (Michelle V. Agins/New York Times)

   (NYT27) MOSCOW -- March 26, 1999 -- RUSSIA-POLICY-2-B&W, 3-26 --
An older woman begs for money in a fashionable Moscow mall. Russia
is in dire straits. The economy is prostrate, Boris Yeltsin's reign
is ending, and the population feels that Russia's market democracy
has largely failed. Though freedom of expression and association
are now widely accepted, the predominant note among Russia watchers
is gloom, often accompanied by recriminations about who is
responsible for the country's plight. (James Hill/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT26) ALBANY, Calif. -- March 26, 1999 -- RUSSIA-POLICY-1,
3-26 -- Martin Malia, emeritus professor of history at the
University of California at Berkeley and author of a new book,
``Russia Under Western Eyes: From the Bronze Horseman to the Lenin
Mausoleum.'' He argues that Russia had no choice but to dismantle
the Communists' command-style economy and try to replace it with a
free market, claiming that a gradual approach would not have been
preferable. (Peter DaSilva/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT25) MILWAUKEE, Wisc. -- March 26, 1999 -- SCHOOL-VOUCHERS-2,
3-26 -- Taylor Stack, a third grader, practices his violin during
music class at Milwaukee's Elementary Creative Arts School, a
public facility, last week. Nine years into the nation's first
school-voucher program in Milwaukee, there is no question that the
concept has taken hold. But few students have used vouchers to
leave schools like Elm Creative, a racially mixed magnet school.
(Todd Buchanan/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT24) MILWAUKEE, Wisc. -- March 26, 1999 -- SCHOOL-VOUCHERS-1,
3-26 -- Brother Bob Smith, president of Messmer High School, left,
talks with students in between classes at the Roman Catholic
school. Nine years into the nation's first school-voucher program
in Milwaukee, there is no question that the concept has taken hold.
More than 6,000 poor children, 6 percent of the city's students,
receive publicly financed vouchers of nearly $5,000 a year to
attend private or parochial schools such as Messmer. (Todd
Buchanan/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT23) MILAN, Italy -- March 26, 1999 -- ONLINE-SHOP-EUROPE,
3-26 -- Cristiano Cora of the Enoteca N'ombra de Vin in Milan lugs
a case of wine due to be sent out to a client of www.vinoplease.it.
While Americans have embraced on-line shopping, Europeans are just
now warming to electronic commerce. (James Hill/New York Times
Photo) *LITE

   (NYT22) UNDATED -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28 --
CAR-SMART-NISSAN-3, 3-26 -- Renault has created a strong base in
Europe by producing daring cars like the Twingo, but it is absent
from North America. Nissan has a much broader lineup, including
trucks, and a presence on every continent, but its recent designs
have often been timid. (New York Times Photo)

   (NYT21) UNDATED -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28 --
CAR-SMART-NISSAN-2, 3-26 -- The Renault Kangoo catches Europe's
eye, above; Nissan's Caravan is sold in Japan. Nissan can certainly
use Renault's help to straighten out its bleak and tangled
finances. But it could also stand a nudge at the drawing board,
some auto industry analysts say. (New York Times Photo)

   (NYT20) UNDATED -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28 --
CAR-SMART-NISSAN-1, 3-26 -- ``We want to please some people,'' says
Patrick Le Quement, Renault's vice president for design and
quality, during last month's introduction of the striking Avantime
concept car, above. In showing off more innovative designs in
recent months (like the NCS sedan, below), the president of Nissan
Design International in San Diego, Jerry Hirshberg, says that
``there's nothing like a good jolt of fear to release the creative
juices.'' (New York Times Photo)

   (NYT19) CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- March 26, 1999 -- CAMPUS-ACTIVISM,
3-26 -- David Charbonneau joins members of Harvard Coalition on
Sexual Assualt during a protest in front of the statue of John
Harvard earlier this month. In the biggest surge in campus activism
in nearly two decades, student protests have burst onto the scene
with a series of rallies, teach-ins and sit-ins protesting various
issues. (Bill Brett/Boston Globe Photos)

   (NY18) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- NY-POLICE-3, 3-26 --
Memorials are seen written Friday next to where bullets fired by
police last month scarred the wall in the lobby of the apartment
building where Amadou Diallo lived. In a case that has sparked 13
days of protests and hundreds of arrests for civil disobedience,
four white police officers have been indicted for second-degree
murder in the shooting death of the unarmed West African immigrant.
Diallo was hit by nearly half of the 41 shots fired by police.
(Richard L. Harbus/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT17) JAZINCE, Macedonia -- March 26, 1999 --
KOSOVO-MACEDONIA-2, 3-26 -- Ethnic Albanian refugees from Kosovo
observe Serb forces on the Yugoslav side of the border with Albania
on Friday. Macedonia fears a massive refugee influx from Kosovo,
where Albanians make up 90 percent of its population. Officials say
Macedonia, about the size of Belgium, is already accommodating
20,000 ethnic Albanian refugees from Kosovo and cannot cope with
more. (Alan Chin/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT16) SKOPJE, Macedonia -- March 26, 1999 -- KOSOVO-MACEDONIA,
3-26 -- Marines guard the U.S. Embassy on Friday following a day of
rioting. Authorities on Friday banned demonstrations in the
Macedonian capital, a day after protests against NATO air strikes
on neighboring Yugoslavia turned violent. (Alan Chin/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT15) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28 --
AERIN-LAUDER-PROFILE-2, 3-26 -- Aerin Lauder, left, with Anna
Wintour, center, at a Christie's auction of Oscar fashions; she
attends several functions a week. Ms. Lauder, 28, is that rarest of
Park Avenue princesses: a hyperactive member of junior society by
night, and by day, a working woman who is being groomed for the
executive suite of one of the country's largest companies. (Philip
Greenberg/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT14) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28 --
AERIN-LAUDER-PROFILE-1, 3-26 -- Aerin Lauder's role at Estee Lauder
ranges from creating colors to helping ad campaigns. Ms. Lauder,
28, is a fixture in a constellation of Young Establishment stars,
the daughters of moneyed and prominent New Yorkers, many of whom
know each other from private schools or Locust Valley, and have
found careers in fashion and style fields. (Nicole Bengiveno/New
York Times Photo) *LITE

   (NYT13) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28 --
CLERGY-WOMEN-FASHION, 3-26 -- The Rev. Christine McSpadden, 35, of
St. Bartholomew's Church (in vestments), finds ways to brighten up
the traditional street garb for priests. ``I always stood out in
Connecticut,'' Ms. McSpadden says of her home state, where priests
who are women usually wear clerical shirts with prim dirndl skirts
and Shetland sweaters. (Michelle V. Agins/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT12) LOS ANGELES -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28
-- CLERGY-WOMEN-FASHION-2, 3-26 -- Canon Anne Richards, 48, of the
Episcopal Diocese of New York, prefers to dress in basic black and
white. ``Jesus said, 'Be like the lilies of the field' - they don't
care what they wear,'' she says. Many women who are rabbis and
ministers, while focused on matters of the spirit, are careful not
to overlook matters like nail polish, hem lengths, heel heights and
hair color. (Nancy Siesel/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT11) LOS ANGELES -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28
-- CLERGY-WOMEN-FASHION-1, 3-26 -- Rabbi Sherre Zwelling, 30, of
Sinai Temple in West Los Angeles finds designer clothes to be a
helpful point of connection with some congregants. ``A woman will
talk to me about my lipstick and makeup and then confide in me that
her husband abuses her,'' she says. ``A conversation might open
with a congregant asking me, 'Did you get those shoes at Prada?'
and then move on to her telling me about her eating disorder.''
(Marissa Roth/New York Times Photo) *LITE

   (NYT10) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- KOSOVO-RDP-2-B&W, 3-26 --
Tenth graders look at a map of Yugoslavia while discussing the
bombings in Kosovo in their history class on Friday. U.S. forces
joined NATO in bombing Yugoslavia for a third day on Friday.
Schools around the nation inserted discussions about the region
into their regular classes. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT9) BABYLON, N.Y. -- March 26, 1999 -- NY-POLICE-2, 3-26 --
Sean Carroll, one of four police officers indicted in the killing
of Amadou Diallo, leaves his home on Friday. In a case that has
sparked 13 days of protests and hundreds of arrests for civil
disobedience, the four white police officers have been indicted for
second-degree murder in the shooting death of the unarmed West
African immigrant. (Maxine Hicks/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT8) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- NY-POLICE, 3-26 -- Jesse
Jackson, left, galvanized protesters outside police headquarters on
Friday as word spread that four white officers had been indicted
for murder in the shooting of an unarmed African immigrant.
Activist Al Sharpton, right, joined Jackson outside police
headquarters on Friday during the protest rally. (Keith Meyers/New
York Times Photo)

   (NYT7) FINLEY, Wash. -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH
28 -- USDA-BEEF-COX, 3-26 -- As his parents Alan and Gerri Almquist
look on, ten-year-old A.J. Almquist explains recently what happened
after he contracted E. coli 0157:H7 from a school lunch in October
1998. The meat used in the school was supplied by the U. S.
Department of Agriculture. Almquist was one of 12 children in the
town who were sickened by the deadly pathogen. (Jackie Johnston/Cox
News Service)

   (NYT6) ST. PETERSBURG, Russia -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR
SUN., MARCH 28 -- RUSSIA-ARMY-COX-3, 3-26 -- An 18-year old Russian
who is dodging the draft attends the weekly meeting of the group
Soldiers' Mothers in St. Petersburg. Scores of committees headed by
parents operate in cities across Russia seeking to help young men
avoid the draft or leave the army. (Paul Miller/Cox News Service)
*LITE

   (NYT5) ST. PETERSBURG, Russia -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR
SUN., MARCH 28 -- RUSSIA-ARMY-COX-2, 3-26 -- Alexandra Shenkarenko
a volunteer with the group Soldiers' Mothers, heads a discussion
about civil rights and the Russian constitution as it pertains to
the Russian military during one of the group's weekly meetings.
Scores of committees headed by parents of army recruits operate in
cities across Russia seeking to help young men avoid the draft or
leave the army. (Paul Miller/Cox News Service)

   (NYT4) ST. PETERSBURG, Russia -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR
SUN., MARCH 28 -- RUSSIA-ARMY-COX-1, 3-26 -- Anatoly, know by his
nickname ``Tolek,'' has been on the run from the Russian army for
three years. During his short few weeks in the service, he says, he
and other recruits were ill-fed and terrorized by violent hazing
within the ranks, and their rations and uniforms were stolen by
officers looking to sell them and pocket the money. (Paul
Miller/Cox News Service)

   (NYT3) UNDATED -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28 --
RUSSIA-RECRUIT-COX, 3-26 -- A Russian tank crew poses with a poster
from the show ``Army Store'' featuring Dana Borisova and her
co-host Alexander Ilyin. Borisova was hired five years ago to host
the show and has gone on to become a Playboy cover model and wildly
popular pinup girl for a deteriorating army that needs all the
morale-boosting it can get. (Cox Newspapers)

   (NYT2) ABOARD THE USS PHILIPPINE SEA -- March 26, 1999 --
KOSOVO-RDP-2, 3-26 -- A Tomahawk cruise missile is launched from
the U.S. Navy cruiser in the Adriatic Sea on Friday. NATO forces
launched their first daylight attack on Yugoslavia on Friday after
two straight nights of raids. (Renso Amariz/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT1) AVIANO AIR BASE, Italy -- March 26, 1999 -- KOSOVO-RDP-1,
3-26 -- Pilots from the 128th Air Refueling Wing, based in
Milwaukee, Wisc., preflight their KC-135 Stratotanker before taking
off from the base Thursday night. The aircraft refuels fighters and
bombers in mid-flight during the NATO air strike campaign on
Yugoslavia. (Senior Airman Jeffrey Allen/New York Times Photo)

   The New York Times News Service
Text:
ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving 03/26/99. Photo clients will
automatically receive these photos via AP's PhotoExpress or may
download them from either the Wieck Photo Database in Dallas at
972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at 305-448-8411.
Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling (888) 603-1036
or 212-556-4204.

Schools around the nation inserted discussions about the region
into their regular classes. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT9) BABYLON, N.Y. -- March 26, 1999 -- NY-POLICE-2, 3-26 --
Sean Carroll, one of four police officers indicted in the killing
of Amadou Diallo, leaves his home on Friday. In a case that has
sparked 13 days of protests and hundreds of arrests for civil
disobedience, the four white police officers have been indicted for
second-degree murder in the shooting death of the unarmed West
African immigrant. (Maxine Hicks/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT8) NEW YORK -- March 26, 1999 -- NY-POLICE, 3-26 -- Jesse
Jackson, left, galvanized protesters outside police headquarters on
Friday as word spread that four white officers had been indicted
for murder in the shooting of an unarmed African immigrant.
Activist Al Sharpton, right, joined Jackson outside police
headquarters on Friday during the protest rally. (Keith Meyers/New
York Times Photo)

   (NYT7) FINLEY, Wash. -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH
28 -- USDA-BEEF-COX, 3-26 -- As his parents Alan and Gerri Almquist
look on, ten-year-old A.J. Almquist explains recently what happened
after he contracted E. coli 0157:H7 from a school lunch in October
1998. The meat used in the school was supplied by the U. S.
Department of Agriculture. Almquist was one of 12 children in the
town who were sickened by the deadly pathogen. (Jackie Johnston/Cox
News Service)

   (NYT6) ST. PETERSBURG, Russia -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR
SUN., MARCH 28 -- RUSSIA-ARMY-COX-3, 3-26 -- An 18-year old Russian
who is dodging the draft attends the weekly meeting of the group
Soldiers' Mothers in St. Petersburg. Scores of committees headed by
parents operate in cities across Russia seeking to help young men
avoid the draft or leave the army. (Paul Miller/Cox News Service)
*LITE

   (NYT5) ST. PETERSBURG, Russia -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR
SUN., MARCH 28 -- RUSSIA-ARMY-COX-2, 3-26 -- Alexandra Shenkarenko
a volunteer with the group Soldiers' Mothers, heads a discussion
about civil rights and the Russian constitution as it pertains to
the Russian military during one of the group's weekly meetings.
Scores of committees headed by parents of army recruits operate in
cities across Russia seeking to help young men avoid the draft or
leave the army. (Paul Miller/Cox News Service)

   (NYT4) ST. PETERSBURG, Russia -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR
SUN., MARCH 28 -- RUSSIA-ARMY-COX-1, 3-26 -- Anatoly, know by his
nickname ``Tolek,'' has been on the run from the Russian army for
three years. During his short few weeks in the service, he says, he
and other recruits were ill-fed and terrorized by violent hazing
within the ranks, and their rations and uniforms were stolen by
officers looking to sell them and pocket the money. (Paul
Miller/Cox News Service)

   (NYT3) UNDATED -- March 26, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., MARCH 28 --
RUSSIA-RECRUIT-COX, 3-26 -- A Russian tank crew poses with a poster
from the show ``Army Store'' featuring Dana Borisova and her
co-host Alexander Ilyin. Borisova was hired five years ago to host
the show and has gone on to become a Playboy cover model and wildly
popular pinup girl for a deteriorating army that needs all the
morale-boosting it can get. (Cox Newspapers)

   (NYT2) ABOARD THE USS PHILIPPINE SEA -- March 26, 1999 --
KOSOVO-RDP-2, 3-26 -- A Tomahawk cruise missile is launched from
the U.S. Navy cruiser in the Adriatic Sea on Friday. NATO forces
launched their first daylight attack on Yugoslavia on Friday after
two straight nights of raids. (Renso Amariz/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT1) AVIANO AIR BASE, Italy -- March 26, 1999 -- KOSOVO-RDP-1,
3-26 -- Pilots from the 128th Air Refueling Wing, based in
Milwaukee, Wisc., preflight their KC-135 Stratotanker before taking
off from the base Thursday night. The aircraft refuels fighters and
bombers in mid-flight during the NATO air strike campaign on
Yugoslavia. (Senior Airman Jeffrey Allen/New York Times Photo)
